abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is adjudged
            satisfactory with project sustainability likely. Both World
            Bank and Borrower performances are rated satisfactory.
            Lessons learned include: It is essential to obtain an
            independent assessment of the extent of the damages and an
            estimate of the costs involved without relying on figures
            provided by inspectors from the housing ministry. Solidarity
            among people affected by an earthquake--or a major
            catastrophe--should not be minimized, but rather supported
            in the project definition. It played a major role in
            reducing by half the number of temporary shelters that had
            to be erected and in helping people who used to live in
            isolated farmhouses resettle in villages where the risk of
            landslides following an earthquake is minimized. The
            director of the project implementation unit and his staff
            should be thoroughly familiar with Bank procurement and
            disbursement procedures before project launching. In the
            case of emergency operations, more flexible disbursement
            procedures are needed. The Bank should make it a standard
            practice to agree to the audit terms of reference at the
            project's outset. Most project design and supervision
            activities should have been awarded to private consulting
            firms; this may have produced solutions more appropriate to
            the special needs of the population. If for security
            reasons, supervision teams cannot make site visits, the Bank
            should consider suspending disbursements.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Emergency Reconstruction Project
            will focus on the short- and medium-term recovery of the
            sectors most affected by the earthquake that struck a
            mountainous area known as Beni Chougrane in the Province of
            Mascara on August 18, 1994. The project aims at rebuilding
            the economic, social, and physical assets that were
            destroyed by the earthquake, with a view to restoring
            essential facilities and services in the shortest possible
            time. The project will include the reconstruction and
            repairs to facilities in the following sectors: a) in
            education; b) in housing; c) in agriculture; d) in public
            health; e) in roads; f) in water supply and sewerage; g) in
            earthquake hazard reduction and prevention; and h) in social
            rehabilitation. The project will address the
            population's social and environmental concerns that
            have surfaced in the aftermath of the earthquake. Particular
            attention will be paid to the needs of women and children.
            The project will also have a major impact on the
            environment. Through rebuilding of the area, the quality of
            the environment will greatly improve, as more structurally
            sound and functional houses will be provided to the
            population, accompanied by good access roads, and better
            water supply and sewerage services.
